issues.description: The problem statement/UML and the code use different method names for the core song-printing operation. The UML and the textual task instructions refer to printFarmSong(), but the template and the solution implement and reference singFarmSong(). This naming mismatch can confuse students about which method to implement (they may search for or implement printFarmSong() while the provided template/tests expect singFarmSong()), causing integration/test failures or unnecessary renaming work.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method name consistent across all artifacts. Either (A) update the problem statement and UML to refer to singFarmSong() everywhere (recommended, since template and solution already use that name), or (B) add/rename a method printFarmSong() in the template/solution (or add a small wrapper printFarmSong() that calls singFarmSong()) and update Main/tests accordingly. Also update the UML and textual task wording so students are not instructed to implement a method name that does not exist in the starter code.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML and task text) asks for a method named printFarmSong(), but both the template and the reference solution define and use a method named singFarmSong(). Main.java in the template and solution calls singFarmSong(). This mismatch (printFarmSong vs singFarmSong) is likely an unintended naming inconsistency and will confuse students about which method to implement and how to run the provided Main/test code.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method name consistent across all artifacts. Either (A) update the problem statement and any tests/instructions to refer to singFarmSong() instead of printFarmSong(), or (B) rename the template and solution methods (and Main calls) from singFarmSong() to printFarmSong(). Recommended minimal fix: change the problem statement task text and UML to use singFarmSong() so it matches the template and solution.
